name: Juegos
desc:
# About this Template

The Scrum Board by [Corrello](https://getcorrello.com/?utm_source=trello&utm_medium=template&utm_campaign=scrum_board) is a Template for a Software Development team following a Scrum process. There are some example Cards on the Board plus some additional details on how to get started in the **How to use this Board** List

## What is Scrum?

Scrum is probably the most popular Agile framework used for Software Development. 

The core of any Scrum process is the **Sprint**. The **Managing your Sprints** Card on this template has some details on setting up and managing Sprints in Trello. Here we will cover a high level overview of running a Scrum process in Trello

## How to use Trello for Scrum?

Trello is a great tool for Scrum teams. They have complete control over their own Boards so can create the process to match how they work. The work is visible everywhere (even if you are fully/partially remote). And finally, pretty much everyone already knows how to use a Trello Board. The most perfect tool in the world is no good if people won't update it!

### Set up your Scrum Board in Trello

This template should help you get started with your Scrum Board. You can customise it if you need to, your Board should evolve to match your process over time.

### Start your Sprint

Exciting times, you're starting your first Sprint! 🏃

The Team's backlog should at this point be in priority order. And those Cards most likely to be pulled into the next Sprint should match your Team's **Definition of Ready** (see below). If you don't have a definition of ready that's not a problem, get started but don't be surprised if some Cards aren't ready to be worked on and can't be accepted into the Sprint.

> **Aside: Definition of Ready** The DoR is the less well known cousin of the *Definition of Done* (see below). Having a Definition of Ready which the team and stakeholders agree on allows everyone to know what needs to be in place before a Card is ready to be worked on. The DoR is likely to evolve over time as you uncover what work can sensibly be done upfront to make development the smoothest. Examples of a DoR could be including acceptance criteria, an explanation of the underlying problem to be solved, wireframes or even high-fidelity designs of any UIs involved etc.
 
The team will decide which Cards to pull off the top of the Backlog into their Sprint. Ideally there is a 'Sprint Goal' they can set which in some way unifies most of these Cards. Having a Sprint Goal ("Improve site search" or "Release Feature A to beta testers") helps set expectations on what the team will achieve during the Sprint. This helps keep the team and stakeholders focussed during the Sprint.

Once the team has what they think is the right number of Cards and has set a Sprint Goal they can discuss how to tackle the Cards. This is where Cards which had some level of planning already can be broken down further and the team can decide who handles what tasks. This step isn't strictly necessary but can be a great way to let the team self-organise on who does what, and to uncover any problems as early as possible in the Sprint.

### Work on your Cards

The team works on the Cards. Each day they should have a standup to discuss where they are at and self-organise on how to move the work forward. 


> **Aside: Running effective standups** If there is one thing I can suggest you change it is how you run your standups. Often the typical approach of asking everyone for a status update results in wasted time and low morale. Instead consider **Walking the Board**. Instead of going person by person, go through your Trello Board Card by Card. Start with those Cards closest to being Done and discuss how to complete them. This can often lead to someone who was about to start something new deciding instead to help complete an already open Card.

If they want to use a Burndown chart they can connect [Corrello](https://getcorrello.com/?utm_source=trello&utm_medium=template&utm_campaign=scrum_board), the [Burndowns Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/5eda444d3be9d07a01eb82a4/burndown-charts-by-corrello) or even just plot one on a Whiteboard.

As Cards match their **Definition of Done** (see below) they are moved into Done.

> **Aside: Definition of Done** The Definition of Done is created by the team in collaboration with stakeholders outside of the team. It says what will happen to a Card before it is considered Done. Typically this could include things like being Tested, Code Reviewed, Analytics added (if required), Final design sign-off and etc. The Team can then make sure those are all ticked off before the Card is marked complete and make sure there are no surprises!

We have added a template Card to this Board which makes it easy to add your Definitions of Ready and Done as checklists to every new Card. When creating a new Card simply use the 'Create from Template' button on the bottom of your Lists.

![Create from Template](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/imagesfortemplates/create_from_template.png)


### End the Sprint

The Sprint is over! great stuff, I hope you hit your Sprint Goal. Time for two key meetings, the Sprint Demo and the Sprint Retrospective.

The **Sprint Demo** is the chance for the team to show the rest of the business what they have been working on. This helps keep everyone up to date on progress and is hopefully a positive experience for the team. If issues are regularly uncovered in the Sprint Demo you may want to look at how the Definition of Done can help uncover these sorts of problems earlier. The Sprint Demo can be in person or over screen sharing. You can also consider recording it for those who can't attend to help keep everyone in the business up to date on progress.

The **Retrospective** is the chance for the Team to review the Sprint and see if there are any changes they want to make to their process. See this article for some ideas specifically on remote retrospectives https://www.atlassian.com/blog/teamwork/run-retrospective-distributed-team-fun

### Start the next Sprint
And away we go again! Rinse and repeat 😊

### Backlog grooming

Throughout all the above someone should be making sure the Backlog is 'groomed'. That just means making sure of 3 things

1. That it is in priority order ready for the next Sprint Planning session 
2. If you are using Story Points, that Cards are estimated
3. For any Cards likely to be in upcoming Sprints they match the **Definition of Ready**

## Before your first Sprint

After reading the above you probably have an idea of some things you might want to tackle before you start your first Sprint. If your team is just getting started with Scrum it is a good time to perform these tasks. 

1. Create the teams **Definition of Done** and **Definition of Ready**
1. Perform any initial backlog grooming, setting points and priorities
1. If the team wants to they could pick a team name

listing.description:
# Trello Export

**One of the [fastest growing power-ups of 2023](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2023/)**

Export from Trello by [Blue Cat](https://www.bluecatreports.com/) lets you export cards from Trello to CSV/Excel, or **set a schedule and get an email export when you want it**.

## How to export from Trello

![Export from Trello](https://exports.bluecatreports.com/listing/export-example.png)

1. Add the Trello Export Power-Up to your board
1. Pick the lists you want to export cards from
1. Click the **Download CSV** button to get your export

## Optional: Set a schedule and get your export emailed directly to you

![Export schedule](https://exports.bluecatreports.com/listing/schedule-example.png)

Paid users can also get exports sent directly to their inbox on a schedule they determine. Simply configure your schedule and we will run the export when you want it and email it to you. You can select daily, weekly or monthly exports and choose the time of day we will create your export for you.

## Pricing

We have two simple options

- **FREE:** 10 Free exports, unlimited boards, custom field support
- **$19/month** Get everything in free plus unlimited exports and scheduled exports to save you time and make sure you never miss an export

## Exporting CSV, Excel, XLSX and Google Sheets data from Trello

Currently Exports by Blue Cat will create a CSV file. These files can easily be opened in Excel or Google sheets and converted to XLSX if required

- To open in Excel, open Excel and open the file the same way you would any other Excel file. You can save this as an XLSX file if you wish.
- To open in Google sheets, open Google sheets, create a new file and select Import. You can then import the CSV file from your computor.

Excel files saved as XLSX can be opened and imported. To import from Google Sheets you will need to save your file as a CSV file from google sheets, which can then be opened and imported.


## How to backup Trello boards for free

Exports by Blue Cat can be a great way to create backups of your Trello data, especially when combined with [Imports by Blue Cat](https://trello.com/power-ups/61fa6cd2cc14647c2c9ee821/import-to-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel) to reload the data. Simply use the free option to create a backup manually or start a paid subscription to create an export automatically on a schedule. The use Imports to import the data back into Trello if you lose anything.

## Once you're done exporting check out our other great tools

### [Blue Cat Reports](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat)

Our Reporting Power-Up is the number one reporting tool for Trello. There is a fully-featured 7-day free trial so give it a go and see the sort of reports you can create now all your data is in Trello. You can [check it out here](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat).

### [Imports](https://trello.com/power-ups/61fa6cd2cc14647c2c9ee821/import-to-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel)

Trello's most popular imports power-up, import data into all the standard Trello fields plus all of your Custom fields.

### [Forms by Blue Cat](https://trello.com/power-ups/6139de588901011c01baf52f/forms-by-blue-cat)

Do you need a way for people to fill out forms and get cards created in Trello? Then look no further. Our [Forms Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/6139de588901011c01baf52f/forms-by-blue-cat) does just that, integrates with all the standard and custom Trello fields as well as attachments. 


## Our Trello guides

See our guide to [Every free Trello power-up](https://www.bluecatreports.com/free-trello-powerups/)

Check out our reviews of [Every Trello reporting power-up](https://www.bluecatreports.com/trello-reporting/)

listing.name: Swimlanes by Blue Cat
listing.description:
**One of the [fastest growing power-ups of 2023](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2023/)**

Finally! The Swimlanes you always wanted for your Trello Boards.

Not only is Swimlanes by Blue Cat **free**, but it is also the only swim lanes tool to work with [Trello custom fields](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/trello-custom-fields-how-to-and-examples/) as well their Labels and Members.

Swimlanes is built by the team behind [Blue Cat Reports](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat), check out our other Power-Ups below. 

*Swimlanes is one of the [fastest growing power-ups of 2022](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2022/)*

## What are swimlanes?

Swimlanes create a view of your Trello boards which looks like the same board shown multiple times stacked on top of itself. Each board only has specific cards, for example, if you group by member each board only shows cards assigned to one member.

![Trello Swimlanes by Member](https://swimlanes.bluecatreports.com/listing/swimlanes.gif)

This is a great way to get an overview of where each team member's work is at in your process. Likewise, grouping by Label or Custom Field can show other useful overviews of your team's cards.

## How to show swimlanes in Trello
Here is how to add swimlanes to your Trello Boards

1. Add the Swimlanes by Blue Cat Power-Up to your Trello board
1. Open the Swimlanes view by clicking the Swimlanes button a the top of your board
1. Select how you want to group cards for your swim lanes from the dropdown in the top right
1. You can group your swim lanes by Label, Member or any custom dropdown or short text field

## How to use swimlanes

Swimlanes are a great way of visualising work in Trello which goes beyond the simple Trello board view. 

### Group by Member to get an overview of everyone's work

By grouping by member you can easily see where each team member's workload is on the board. Have they got enough/too-much work coming up? Have they got too much in progress already?

### Group by Custom Field to see your process with your data

If you have a custom field for **Priority**, easily see where each priorities work is in your process.  

Using a **Status** custom field? Then easily see a breakdown of work by status for your boards.

If you track **Epics** or **Projects** as custom fields you can group by those and see how each epic/project is progressing on your board. This is great for showing as part of a progress report as it lets people easily see progress against these higher-level objectives using the data from your Trello boards.

Interested in more powerful custom field reporting options? Including email reports sent right o your inbox? Then do check out the best reporting tool for Trello [Blue Cat Reports](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat)
 
### Drag and Drop between swimlanes

You can even drag and drop cards within the swimlanes view. Doing this lets you add and remove members or labels, and update custom field values. You can also drag between lists just as you would in Trello.

## Our other Power-Ups

### [Blue Cat Reports](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat)

Our Reporting Power-Up is the number one reporting tool for Trello. There is a fully-featured 7-day free trial so give it a go and see the sort of reports you can create now all your data is in Trello. You can [check it out here](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat).

### [Forms by Blue Cat](https://trello.com/power-ups/6139de588901011c01baf52f/forms-by-blue-cat)

Do you need a way for people to fill out forms and get cards created in Trello? Then look no further. Our [Forms Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/6139de588901011c01baf52f/forms-by-blue-cat) does just that, integrates with all the standard and custom Trello fields as well as attachments. 

### [Import to Trello by Blue Cat](https://trello.com/power-ups/61fa6cd2cc14647c2c9ee821/trello-import-by-blue-cat)

Easily import CSV, Excel and Google Sheets into Trello with our FREE [Imports Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/61fa6cd2cc14647c2c9ee821/import-to-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel)

### [Exports for Trello](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel)

Export your data from Trello, manually for free or pay to get scheduled exports direct to your inbox. Our [Exports Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel) does just that.

## Our Trello guides

See our guide to [all the free Trello power-ups](https://www.bluecatreports.com/free-trello-powerups/)

Check out our reviews of [all the Trello reporting power-ups](https://www.bluecatreports.com/trello-reporting/)

listing.name: Import to Trello by Blue Cat (CSV, Excel)
listing.description:
Trello Import by [Blue Cat](https://www.bluecatreports.com/) lets you import cards from CSV or Excel spreadsheets directly into your Trello boards.

*Hey! we're one of the [fastest growing power-ups of 2022](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2022/) and [2023](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2023/)!*

## Watch the video!

We're very happy that Brittany from [How I Trello](https://trello.substack.com/) created this short video showing how to use the power-up. Check it out, or read on below if you prefer. 

[![](https://imports.bluecatreports.com/listing/imports_youtube.png)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZkPKD9TNy1M)

## How to import into Trello

![Select Excel, XLSX or CSV file to Import into Trello](https://imports.bluecatreports.com/listing/select-file.png)

1. Add the Trello Import Power-Up to your board
1. Open the CSV or Excel file you want to import
1. Select how to map your data into Trello
1. Click the import button and wait as we create all your cards for you

## Select how we map your data into Trello
![Field mapping for your Trello Import](https://imports.bluecatreports.com/listing/mappings.png)

For each column in your spreadsheet, you can select how we will import it into your Trello board. For data you don't want to match to a specific field in Trello you can simply add it to the card description.

If there is data we cannot import we will show that here so you can see what the issue is. You can expand sections to get additional information. To correct these errors you will either need to create the matching List/Label/Custom Field/etc on your Trello board or update your spreadsheet to change those values to match Trello. Or, you can ignore those issues and import the spreadsheet without that data.

## Importing CSV, Excel and Google Sheets data to Trello

Excel files saved as XLSX can be opened and imported. To import from Google Sheets you will need to save your file as a CSV file from google sheets, which can then be opened and imported.

The first row of the spreadsheet is used as headings so we know how to map the data into Trello. 

You can take a look at a [simple example spreadsheet here](https://imports.bluecatreports.com/listing/Example%20Import%20Spreadsheet.csv) or any export created from in Trello can be imported using this power-up

We can handle all of these field names, they will be mapped into Trello as described below. 

- name, title or card name: Any of these will be mapped to the **card name**
- description, card description or desc: Any of these will map to the **card description**
- list: the **name of the list** we should import this card into. If we cannot find that list the card is created in the first list on the board
- members: the names of the members to assign this card to
- labels: the names and/or colours of the labels to add to this card
- due or due date: maps to the card due date
- **Checklists**
 - Checklist: The **Checklist name** to import this checklist item into 
 - Checklist item: The **Checklist item name**
 - Checklist item due: The **due date** for this checklist item
 - Checklist item member: The **assigned member** for this checklist item

### Errors in your spreadsheets

We will let you know if any of the data cannot be mapped into Trello, if you are happy with that then you can ignore the warnings and import. If there are issues during the import those will be reported once the import is complete.


## Import a backup file to Trello

If you take a backup of your Boards using [Trello's export feature](https://www.bluecatreports.com/trello-reporting/exporting-trello-data/#trelloBoardExport) you can then use our free import tool to recreate any lost or changed data. Either import the entire spreadsheet to recreate everything, or edit it beforehand to select just the cards you want to recreate.

## Pricing

Imports by Blue Cat is **free for your first 10 imports**, after that it costs $19/month (or $190/year) for unlimited imports.

## Once you're done importing check out our other great tools

### [Blue Cat Reports](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat)

Our Reporting Power-Up is the number one reporting tool for Trello. There is a fully-featured 7-day free trial so give it a go and see the sort of reports you can create now all your data is in Trello. You can [check it out here](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat).

### [Forms by Blue Cat](https://trello.com/power-ups/6139de588901011c01baf52f/forms-by-blue-cat)

Do you need a way for people to fill out forms and get cards created in Trello? Then look no further. Our [Forms Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/6139de588901011c01baf52f/forms-by-blue-cat) does just that, integrates with all the standard and custom Trello fields as well as attachments. 

### [Exports for Trello](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel)

Export your data from Trello, manually for free or pay to get scheduled exports direct to your inbox. Our [Exports Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel) does just that.

## Our Trello guides

See our guide to [every free Trello power-up](https://www.bluecatreports.com/free-trello-powerups/)

Check out our reviews of [every Trello reporting power-up](https://www.bluecatreports.com/trello-reporting/)

listing.name: Forms by Blue Cat
listing.description:
[![Top Trello Power-Ups from 2021](https://www.bluecatreports.com/img/awards/top-new-trello-power-up-2021.png)](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2021/)

*Also, one of the [fastest growing power-ups of 2022](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2022/)* and [2023!](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2023/)

# Create Custom Forms for Trello

Forms by Blue Cat lets you create forms which will create Cards on your Trello boards. You have full control over sending data straight to any fields in Trello, including your custom fields and attachments.

### Features

1. **Custom field support** Add any of your custom fields to your forms, we populate the custom fields when we create your Cards
2. **Attachments** Add attachment/document upload to your forms, we will add anything uploaded to the attachements section of the created Card in Trello. 
3. **Email notifications** Get an email notification of any new forms completed
4. **Standard card fields** Add any of the standard card fields (ie Due dates, Labels etc.) to your forms. Including long text fields which can populate the Card description
5. **Select list** You can select the list we create your Cards in.
6. **Conditional Logic** You can set fields in your Forms to show/hide based on otehr selections on your Forms. No need for giant forms and make sure you get the information you need.
7. **Automation support** Because all of the data we create is populated into the standard or Custom Trello Card fields all of Trello's automations are available to you. See [how to use automations with forms here](https://www.bluecatforms.com/help/articles/automations/)
8. **Export all your form data** Again, because all of the data from your forms is simply stored in Trello you can export your Trello forms data easily to CSV/Excel at any time. See [how to export your Foms data](https://www.bluecatforms.com/help/articles/exports/) for more details.
9. **Create reports from your forms** Our recommended approach is to use [Blue Cat Reports](https://www.bluecatreports.com/) to [generate reports from your Trello forms data](https://www.bluecatforms.com/help/articles/reports/)


## What our customers are saying!

> *"We are using Forms by Blue Cat for our service ticket system for customers. Before, we were using Google Forms and Zapier to create cards in Trello. It was slow and expensive to operate. With Forms by Blue Cat the process is so much simpler, faster and we have added the ability for customers to attach photos with their cards*"

> **Hunter Jisha** [Good Faith Energy](https://goodfaithenergy.com/)

### The only forms solution fully integrated with your Trello boards

Forms by Blue Cat is the only forms solution which lets you populate all your Trello card fields, custom fields and add attachments. See [9 ways teams are using Forms for Trello](https://www.bluecatforms.com/help/articles/inspiration/)

## Watch the video
We're very happy that Brittany from [How I Trello](https://trello.substack.com/) created this short video showing how to use the power-up. Check it out, or read on below if you prefer.
[![](https://app.bluecatforms.com/public/images/puplisting/forms_youtube_2.webp)](https://youtu.be/DSg2sYvk-2w)


## How to create Forms for Trello

The process is simple

1. Add the **Forms by Blue Cat** Power-Up to the Board you want to create a form for
1. Pick the fields or custom fields you want from your cards to add to the form, drag and drop to rearrange
1. You can also add form fields which will populate your card description
1. Use conditional logic to show/hide fields based on other selections
1. (optional) Set your welcome and thank you messages
1. Publish your form!
1. We turn completed forms into Trello cards!

### Create forms directly within Trello
![Blue Cat Forms for Trello](https://app.bluecatforms.com/public/images/puplisting/forms_list.png)


### Easy Drag and Drop editor lets you create forms from all your card fields
![Edit Forms within Trello](https://app.bluecatforms.com/public/images/puplisting/form_editor.png)

### We send completed forms to Trello
![Blue Cat Forms for Trello](https://app.bluecatforms.com/public/images/puplisting/example_form.png)

## What our customers are saying!

> *"Blue Cat Forms has been amazing! It has allowed us to have a clean and transparent way to gather the required information from our clients. The form itself is VERY easy to setup. Prior to Blue Cat Forms, I was using an email template that created a new card in our company trello board. It got the job done but there was a lot of room for human error. With Blue Cat Forms, you can make things dropdowns to narrow down the responses AND can make fields required so they cannot skip out on details. It even populates the custom fields we have opposed to me having to manually pull that information from the email they submitted! Overall, I am so excited this launched and cannot waiting to incorporate it into our Blue Cat Reports to be able to analyze the company as whole."*

> **Dana Lang** [Top Shelf Processing](https://mytspros.com/)

## Other ways to use Forms by Blue Cat

Customer Satisfaction surveys

- Once a job is complete, send a form to your customers to collect feedback on how the job went

Collecting leads from your website

- Put a link to a form or embed it on your website. Potential leads can fill out all the data you need then your team can follow up from within Trello.

Data entry 

- By using Forms by Blue Cat you can make sure people fill out the data you need and don't miss a thing.

Collecting beta users for your product launch

- We did this with the beta of Forms, it worked really well (blog post coming soon hopefully)

Collect suggestions from customers, employees and more

- A simple form your employees can use to fill out to give you suggestions
- A form you can send to your customers to get feedback on your product or service

Collect job applicants into your recruitment process

- A simple form, including the ability to upload a CV/Resume, add a cover letter and select various custom fields for your cards. Then keep your whole process nice and organised in Trello!

Manage orders for a shop or manufacturing business

- Your customers can fill out orders with a form, then your team manages the process in Trello.

And so much more... 😺

## Pricing

**Free plans** come with
- Unlimited forms
- Standard Trello card fields support
- Custom field support
- Conditional logic
- 10 responses a month

**Basic - $29/month**
- Everything in Free tier
- File uploads (5mb limit)
- 100 responses a month

**Pro - $59/month**
- Everything in Basic
- File uploads (50mb limit)
- Set your own branding
- Unlimited users
- 1,000 responses a month

**Business - $99/month**
- Everything in Pro
- 10,000 responses a month
 
Save money with annual plans - **get 2 months free!**

## What our customers are saying!
 
> *"I can see so much potential for this power-up, and if you have any use case where you want to get info in Trello without requiring someone to create a card, THIS is your solution."*

> **Brittany Joiner** [How I Trello](https://trello.substack.com/)

## The most complete forms for Trello

See how we compare to the alternatives

### Jotform for Trello

Jotform has a Trello Power-Up and allows you to attach links to your forms to the back of your cards. Or to attach reports and submissions from forms to the back of your cards. It is not really meant for publishing forms to collect data and create cards in Trello. Great if you already use JotForm and want to track responses in Trello, not so good for creating cards in Trello from you forms.

### Typeform for Trello

Typeform has a Power-Up for Trello and allows you to attach a single Typeform to a board. Responses to that form will create new cards and the response data is shown on the back of the cards. However, the data is not actually stored in Trello, so you can't use Typeform to set card labels, descriptions or custom fields etc. And since the data isn't in Trello you can't make use of automations based on the submitted data or any of the reporting options in Trello.

### Google forms for Trello

Google forms has no Trello power-up so you need to create and manage your forms outside of Trello. Google forms also requires you to create your own integration to get responses into Trello. This can be done with tools like [Zapier](https://zapier.com/) but will require a fair amount of work, is likely to be slow to operate, may not support all the fields in Trello and adds additional cost and complexity.

### Gravity forms for Trello

Gravity forms has no Trello power-up so you need to create and manage your forms outside of Trello. Gravity Forms does have a Trello add-on to their tool and can populate the core card fields. There is no support for custom fields though.

### Cognito forms for Trello

Cognito forms has no Trello power-up so you need to create and manage your forms outside of Trello. Cognito forms also requires you to create your own integration to get responses into Trello. This can be done with tools like [Zapier](https://zapier.com/) but will require a fair amount of work, is likely to be slow to operate and may not support all the fields in Trello. Also, having to use 2 tools to get things working adds cost and complexity.

### Ninja forms for Trello

Ninja forms has no Trello power-up so you need to create and manage your forms on their site. Ninja forms also requires you to create your own integration to get responses into Trello. This can be done with tools like [Zapier](https://zapier.com/) but will require a fair amount of work, is likely to be slow/expensive to operate and may not support all the fields in Trello.


## Our other Power-Ups for Trello

**Corrello [Scrum and Kanban charts](https://trello.com/power-ups/568c2b6c7d2758a55ac48c98/agile-scrum-kanban-dashboards-charts-corrello)**. Burndowns, CFDs, Cycle Time, Release Forecasts and more.

**[Kanban WIP](https://trello.com/power-ups/5e621e477907d7774380f551/kanban-wip-by-corrello)**. Allows you to set up WIP limits which will apply across multiple lists.

**[Agile Tools](https://trello.com/power-ups/59d4ef8cfea15a55b0086614/agile-tools-by-corrello)**. Lets you add story points to cards (integrates with Corrello) and set WIP limits for individual lists.

**[Time in List](https://trello.com/power-ups/5b4765f383dd7c75d8e57be4/time-in-list)**. Does what it says on the tin! Super simple time in list tracking for Trello.

Looking for general purpose **[Trello Reporting](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat)?** Blue Cat Reports is our general purpose Reporting solution for Trello. Build the charts you want, drag and drop to create the dashboard how your team needs it.


[Import to Trello by Blue Cat](https://trello.com/power-ups/61fa6cd2cc14647c2c9ee821/trello-import-by-blue-cat) lets you easily import CSV, Excel and Google Sheets into Trello.

### [Exports for Trello](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel)

Export your data from Trello, manually for free or pay to get scheduled exports direct to your inbox. Our [Exports Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel) does just that.

## Our Trello guides

See our guide to [all the free power-ups for Trello](https://www.bluecatreports.com/free-trello-powerups/)

Check out our reviews of [every reporting power-up available](https://www.bluecatreports.com/trello-reporting/)

listing.description:
**One of the [fastest growing power-ups of 2023](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2023/)**

Check out our [quick demo video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7kWckhpFWoM) for a quick overview of Blue Cat Reports for Trello 😻

![Blue Cat Reports for Trello Demo Video](https://www.bluecatreports.com/img/landing/demo_video.webp)

[Watch it here!](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7kWckhpFWoM)


## Flexible Project Management & Reporting Power Up for your Trello Boards

Blue Cat [Reports for Trello](https://bluecatreports.com/) is the top level view of your Trello Boards. Fully customisable reporting over any number of Boards.

**Team members** can keep track of tasks spread across multiple Boards.
**Managers** can keep tabs on productivity and capacity. 

> *"Blue Cat Reports enabled our company to pull & present data from Trello that we haven’t been able to uncover with any other add-ons. **The reports are easy to create, fully customizable and beautifully designed.**"*
> 
> Megan Ruediger *Schmidt Family of Companies*

## Generate in-depth custom reports: see the status of every card on every board

Create the Reports you want, with the charts you want, and get them when you want!

- Reporting on data from multiple Boards
- Create the charts you want: Pie/Bar/Historical/Counts/Time to Complete
- ...with the data you want, select Cards and Checklist Items based on Boards, Lists, Labels, Members, Custom Fields, Due dates, time in list... (I could go on!)
- Get your reports emailed to you (or anyone) on a schedule you want
- Display your Reports on a screen in the office and watch them update live

Let's take a look at some example reports :)

## Reporting to keep tabs on productivity and capacity
We know how it goes...
💡 Someone asks *how much work your team is getting done? How long things take? Who's doing the most? Which types of work are getting requested most often?* etc....
🤓 Maybe you could get the data from Trello yourself! then wrangle it in Excel.
😬 But now you're stuck reporting that every week!
🥺 Then someone wants to know something new, so your new job just got even bigger!

Let's give you and your managers more than you could ever need. With Blue Cat Reports you can create a management update with the reporting they need... 
- Who is doing what?
- How long work is taking?
- How much work is being added over time?
- Who is requesting the most work? (by client or department etc.)
- Pretty much anything else you might want to know (win/lose rates for sales teams, deal value by marketing channel...)
- Then set this up to email you and anyone else who needs it before your meeting. It couldn't be easier!
![Analytical Reporting](https://app.bluecatreports.com/public/images/pup-listing/DL_Monthly%20Analytics.png)

All these charts are easy to create and can be placed where you want them in your Report. 


## Reporting to keep tabs on your process
🤗 You've got your data in Trello, yay!
😬 But things keep getting missed 
😟 you're not sure you or your team really know what is the priority each day or week
🙃 Let's turn that frown around!

Keep yor team on track at your weekly or daily team meeting (we do ours every Monday after lunch). Create a report for your team meeting to show

- Any tasks needing work right now
- Any tasks which have spent too long in a certain list (great for managing SLAs)
- Any tasks overdue or due this week
- All outstanding tasks by member: is anyone overloaded?
- Any flagged tasks (urgent, expedite, etc.)
- Again, get this (or any) report sent to your inbox exactly when you need it. Or stick it up on a screen in the office and watch the numbers update in realtime!

![Operational Reporting](https://app.bluecatreports.com/public/images/pup-listing/DL_Monday%20update.png)

## Daily and Weekly Task Tracking For Your Teams
Do your team members have cards spread across various boards? Maybe they are relying on setting calendar reminders to check their Boards? But then they see something else and get distracted... What should be a 30 minute task to keep everything moving ends up taking all morning and things still get missed!

No longer! 

Create a **Quick List** for each team member showing their open tasks. You can select everything assigned to them, across any number of Boards. You can see Cards based on List, Due Date or anything else you ight think of. Or create a list of Checklist items for them :)

![Daily Todo List reporting for Trello](https://app.bluecatreports.com/public/images/pup-listing/daily%20todo%20list.png)

## Create analytics dashboards & project summary reports

Ideal for weekly or monthly management reporting. You can create reports showing summaries of work remaining and work completed. See how much work has been added to the project vs completed. See who the work is assigned to and calculate if you have the resources you need to complete your project.

For people not used to opening Trello you can configure email reports to send this analysis straight to their inbox. Or invite everyone in and let them see the live reporting themselves.

## Generate in-depth custom reports: see the status of every card on every board

With Blue Cat Reports you can pull any data you could reasonably want from Trello. There are no limitations on the Boards you select to report on. Reports can include Cards and Checklist Items from multiple Boards easily. Then configure the data you want to see from them. We can pull all your Custom Field data as well, report and query on that as well as display it in the reports.

With our drilldowns you can open each chart to see additional information and even further analyse the data.

## Pricing

Add the power-up to start a 7 day free trial. Pricing is then $4/member monthly on the boards you enable reporting on. Enterprise pricing options and discounts for large teams are available, please contact [sales@bluecatreports.com](mailto:sales@bluecatreports.com) for details.

## Reporting for Marketing Teams

Easily track things like 

- Scheduled Cards by Team Member, Status, Client, Business Objective, etc
- Completed Cards broken down any way you like
- Completed Cards over time
- Arrival rates
- Time to Complete
- More more more! Check out our example [Trello Marketing team Reports]( https://www.bluecatreports.com/help/categories/marketing/)

## Reporting for Sales Teams

Easily track things like 

- Sales conversion win/loss rate (total and by sales rep etc.)
- Sales trend analysis
- Funnel metrics (total size or broken down by hot/warm/cold and etc)
- Sales cycle length (total or by member)
- New leads added over time
- Select to show deal value instead of Card count for any charts

## Reporting for Project Management

Create your reports with charts for

- Lead Time, Cycle Time and/or Time to Market
- WIP (Work in Progress) over time (total or broken down by member, category, etc)
- Productivity, Cards or Hours completed (total or broken down by assignee)
- Hours remaining
- Resource utilisation

----

> _"Blue Cat reports have been a tremendous help in allowing us to understand and improve our workflow process.  **The reports are easy to use and just one click away!**"_
> Natalie Hecker  _[successacademies.org](http://successacademies.org/)_

Any questions? Drop us an email at  [support@bluecatreports.com](mailto:support@bluecatreports.com)


## Our other Power-Ups for Trello

**[Trello Forms](https://trello.com/power-ups/6139de588901011c01baf52f/forms-by-blue-cat)**. The easiest to use, most complete Forms solution for Trello.

**Corrello [Scrum and Kanban charts](https://trello.com/power-ups/568c2b6c7d2758a55ac48c98/agile-scrum-kanban-dashboards-charts-corrello)**. Burndowns, CFDs, Cycle Time, Release Forecasts and more.

**[Kanban WIP](https://trello.com/power-ups/5e621e477907d7774380f551/kanban-wip-by-corrello)**. Allows you to set up WIP limits which will apply across multiple lists.

**[Agile Tools](https://trello.com/power-ups/59d4ef8cfea15a55b0086614/agile-tools-by-corrello)**. Lets you add story points to cards (integrates with Corrello) and set WIP limits for individual lists.

**[Time in List](https://trello.com/power-ups/5b4765f383dd7c75d8e57be4/time-in-list)**. Does what it says on the tin! Super simple time in list tracking for Trello.


**[Import to Trello by Blue Cat](https://trello.com/power-ups/61fa6cd2cc14647c2c9ee821/trello-import-by-blue-cat)** lets you easily import CSV, Excel and Google Sheets into Trello.

### [Exports for Trello](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel)

Export your data from Trello, manually for free or pay to get scheduled exports direct to your inbox. Our [Exports Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel) does just that.

## Our Trello guides

See our guide to [every free power-up on Trello](https://www.bluecatreports.com/free-trello-powerups/)

Check out our reviews of [every reporting power-up for Trello](https://www.bluecatreports.com/trello-reporting/)

listing.name: Time in List by Blue Cat
listing.description:
**One of the [fastest growing power-ups of 2023](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2023/)**

From the creators of [Blue Cat Reports](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat)

> *"This instantly became one of my favorite Trello Powerups. Knowing how long individual tasks have remained in a given state (list) is incredibly powerful for our use case."*
> **Natalie Heker** [Success Academies]

> *"Like Card Aging but done well"* 
> **Tom Sandford** [Founder Future Content]

> *"We utilized this board HEAVILY for full scale kanban production cards. Time in List was a game changer - without having to open any cards we could see exactly how long it had been in the current list... set parameters around that for red flags and such as well. And the ability to dig in and see all of the history at a glance was awesome."*
> **Robby Baker** [Marketing Director Holtz Leather co.]

## Get started right now

It couldn't be simpler! **Add the Time In List Power-Up** to your boards and see...

### How long each card has been in the current list

On the front of every card, and (optionally) how long it has been on the current board 
 
- Spot slow cards
- Track performance against SLAs
- See which tasks need to get moving today
![Time on cards](https://app.timeinlist.com/public/images/landing/front-badges_ipadair2_gold_landscape.png)

### How long cards spent in past lists

On the back of your cards. 

- For each card, see which part of the process took the longest
-  We load and display a full history for all cards as soon as the Power-Up is enabled
![Time in past lists](https://app.timeinlist.com/public/images/landing/time-in-past-lists.png)

### Charts showing aggregate data

- See which parts of your process are consistently the slowest
- Get averages per list
- Filter by **member** or **label**

![Charts](https://app.timeinlist.com/public/images/landing/chart.png)


### Time In List for Trello is the Power-Up your team is missing right now. 

* Spot the stuck cards, **who needs help today?**
* See which parts of your process take the longest, **How could you go faster in future?**
* Track performance against SLAs
* See which cards never make it off your todo list
* Measure your process and improve :)

Start your free trial **add Time In List to your Trello boards today**

### Pricing

- Monthly $3/member on your board/s
- Annual (2 months free!) $30/member 
- Note: the same member on multiple boards only counts once

Got questions? Drop us a line at support@timeinlist.com :)


## Our other Power-Ups for Trello

listing.description:
> *"**Corrello has transformed Trello from a delightful way to organize work into a powerful agile project management tool.** If you are using Trello to manage any Scrum, Kanban or other agile process, **get Corrello now. You are flying blind without it**."*
> - Chris Brookins (CPO **HelpScout**)

*NEWS: Corrello was one of the [fastest growing power-ups of 2022](https://www.bluecatreports.com/blog/power-up-stats-2022/)*
![Scrum team Burndown](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/powerup/burndown.png)


> *"The best agile tool for Trello"*
> Anita Taylor (PM **Stack Overflow**) 




## Detailed metrics for Scrum and Kanban teams

Corrello is a Scrum and Kanban extension that instantly and seamlessly integrates with Trello. Connect Corrello today and get the charts you need in seconds. 
- **You** can get the charts and reports you need for true agile project management
-  **Your team** can continue using the tool they love

![Agile Metrics for Trello](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/powerup/cfd.png)

## Analytics and charts for your Scrum boards
With Corrello’s **burndown** charts you have the everything you need to keep your team on track day to day during your sprints. You can also review past sprints and velocity during your retrospectives to help your team improve their Scrum process. 

Corrello also fully integrates with [Story Points](https://trello.com/power-ups/59d4ef8cfea15a55b0086614/agile-tools-by-corrello) from the Agile Tools power-up

## Reporting and Analytics for your Kanban boards

With Corrello’s **CFD** and **Cycle Time** charts you have the everything you need to show your team how they are working and help them identify the bottlenecks where they can improve. Our **WIP Age** charts help direct daily activity. 

## Estimate your progress and backlogs

Corrello also helps with reporting outside the team. Our **Burnup** chart tracks progress towards completion of an overall project goal on your Scrum or Kanban boards.

## 'Master' your Agile Project management with Corrello's reporting and analytics

Corrello offers all the charts, metrics and analytics you need to track and analyze your team's progress, including:

### Burndown charts
Manage your Sprints and stay on schedule with the Sprint Burndown chart. Burndown charts show the number of cards outstanding in your sprint each day, burning down to 0 at the end of your sprint (hopefully)

![Scrum team Burndown](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/powerup/burndown.png)

#### What is a Burndown Chart?

A Burndown Chart (or Sprint Burndown Chart) is used by Scrum teams to track progress through the Sprint. There will be an *ideal* line plotted showing how many cards or points would be completed each day assuming all work is completed by the end of the Sprint. There will also be an *actual* line showing the amount of work remaining each day. By the end of the sprint the *actual* line should be at 0 and there is no work remaining.

#### How is a Burndown Chart Calculated?

The *actual* burndown line is plotted to show the amount of work remaining each day (the work which needs to burndown). The *ideal* line on a Burndown Chart shows how much work would be remaining each day if all work was completed in the sprint. The ideal line assumes the same amount of work will be completed each day. As work is completed you will see the actual line burndown towards the bottom of the chart.

#### How to use a Burndown Chart in Scrum?

![How to use a Burndown Chart](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/explainers/burndown-what-is.png)

During the Sprint it is useful to compare your *actual* burndown to your *ideal* burndown. If you are above the ideal then you are behind schedule (this may not be uncommon in the early parts of your Sprint). If you are on or below the ideal line then you are ahead of schedule. If you are very far behind you may want to remove some work from the Sprint so you can complete what is left. If you are very far ahead you may want to add some more work. If you often end up adding or removing work you will probably want the team to look carefully at how much work they add in to future sprints to try and avoid that.

### Cycle Time charts

See Cycle and Lead times for your Trello boards. Broken down with a Control Chart and Cycle Time Histogram. The list by list breakdown of cycle times helps you identify bottlenecks with your teams.

![Cycletime chart for Kanban](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/powerup/cycle_time.png)

#### What is a Cycle Time Chart?

Cycle Time is a measure of the time elapsed between work starting and work being completed on a task. A Cycle Time Chart (or Control Chart) shows each card completed with the date it was completed on the x-axis. The number of days it took to complete is plotted against the y-axis.

Cycle Time is also often plotted on a histogram showing the cycle time days on the x-axis. The number of tasks which took that long to complete are plotted against the y-axis. This can be useful to see how long cards typically take to complete.

#### How to use a Cycle Time Chart?

![How to use a Cycle Time Chart](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/explainers/cycle-time-what-is.png)

Cycle Time Charts can be used to find outliers (cards which took unusually long to complete). This can be useful for discussions with the team on how the process could be improved. 

You can also look at the cycle time trends over time, to see if cycle time is steady or improving/worsening. If cycle time is increasing over time you may want to look at how much work the team is taking on at once. Often longer cycle times are a result of teams taking on too much work and losing time to context switching.

#### How is Cycle Time Calculated?

Cycle Time is a measure of the time elapsed between work starting on a task and work being completed. Cycle time is typically recorded in days, with any partial days being rounded up. A task started and completed in the same day will record 1 day of cycle time.

#### Cycle Time vs Lead Time

Cycle Time is a measure of time to complete work from when work is started on it. Lead time is a measure of time to complete work from when the work is committed to. It is likely that your external partners may be more interested in lead time. Internally Cycle Time may be the more useful measure for the team, but being aware of Lead Time can also be useful.

### Cumulative Flow Diagram

Check for bottlenecks with our CFD chart. See where work builds up in individual lists. Or quickly filter to see WIP or Backlog lists only and see how your board is behaving

![Kanban team CFD Cumulative Flow Diagram](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/powerup/cfd.png)

#### What is a Cumulative Flow Diagram?

A Cumulative Flow Diagram tracks the number of cards in each list at the end of each day, and accumulates cards in done at the bottom of the chart. This can be useful to see how cards move through the whole process and can often help identify bottlenecks in the system.

#### What can you learn from a Cumulative Flow Diagram?

![How does a CFD work](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/explainers/cfd-what-is.png)

You can learn these things from your Cumulative Flow Diagram

- Is WIP (Work In Progress) building up over time?
- Is the Backlog building up over time?
- Is work in any individual lists building up over time?
- Is work getting done at a constant rate?

If WIP is building up, it would be a good idea to try and focus the team on completing existing work before starting anything new.

If the Backlog is building up, you may want to be careful about committing to more work before the team has completed some of what it has already committed to.

Individual lists building up can show a bottleneck around that list, talk to the team to see if anything can be done to get the cards in that list moving.

### WIP Age Charts

See cycle time issues before they become a problem, stop starting and start finishing with our WIP Age view! Easily see cards which have been in their current list, or in progress, longer than average.

![WIP Age for Trello Kanban Teams](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/explainers/wip-age-what-is.png)

#### What does WIP mean?

WIP stands for Work In Progres. It is a count of all the work current in progress. Teams often try to limit WIP to ensure they aren't losing time to context switching.

#### What is WIP Aging?

WIP Aging measures the age of current in progress tasks. This is as opposed to Cycle Time which measures the age of completed work. By looking at the age of in progress tasks you can focus your team on the oldest tasks and make sure work gets through the process at a consistent pace.

#### Do lower WIP limits improve Flow?

Lower WIP limits often improve throughput of a process. We could talk about [Little's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little%27s_law), but it is simpler to think of a simple example. Imagine a single person wrapping christmas presents. If they try to wrap 10 all at once they will complete them all at the same time, but until then none are complete. By completing them one at a time they can get some presents wrapped sooner. And by keeping things simpler for themselves, focusing on a single task at a time, they can probably finish faster.


### Burnup Charts

Track progress towards your goals and forecast when work will be completed with our release forecast burnup chart. Work remaining on your backlog is charted as the upper line, work completed is burnt up towards the total. We forecast a projection forward showing when you will likely complete your current backlog.

![Backlog forecast burnup chart for Trello](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/burnup.png)

#### What is a Burnup Chart?

A burnup chart tracks the total scope of the project, and the work completed in the project. The work completed 'burns up' towards the total scope line.

#### How do you read a Burnup Chart?

The upper line is the total scope of the project, when tasks are added it will move up and when tasks are removed it will move down. The lower line is the amount of work completed in the project. As tasks are completed this line burns up towards the total scope. When you look at Burnup charts it becomes apparent that the rate work is completed remains pretty steady over time. The easiest way to get the project completed on a specific date is often to reduce (or stop adding!) scope.

## Kanban metrics and analytics software for trello

Corrello is ideal for both Scrum and Kanban teams, or those teams working with a mix of both Scrum and Kanban (Scrumban anyone!)

> *"This is a *really* nice product. I'm really happy with what you've built here. It's everything I need in a Scrum/Kanban tool and nothing I don't. Blows JIRA completely out of the water."*
> Scott McCoy (Software Engineer at **OpenX**)

> *"**Corrello gives us actionable data we use to effectively manage our development process**, without the team needing to do anything new and without any changes needed to their workflow."*
> Sam Stagg (VP Eng **Pusher**)

> *"The best agile tool for Trello"*
> Anita Taylor (PM **Stack Overflow**) 

## [FAQs]

### How do I use trello as a Kanban board?

Trello boards are naturally Kanban boards. Simply…

- Create your new Trello Board (give it a name!)
- Map out your process (from todo to done) as Lists on your Board
- [Optional] Add the List Limits Power-Up and set WIP limits for your lists
- Create Cards for each task
- [Optional] create Checklists on Cards if you have subtasks
- Invite your team and assign members to Cards 
- Add labels (ie Bug, Blocked) to Cards if needed
- [Optional] if you really want to get the most from Kanban it is worth installing a Power-Up like [Corrello Agile Metrics](https://trello.com/power-ups/568c2b6c7d2758a55ac48c98/agile-dashboards-by-corrello) 

### How do I use Trello as a Scrum board?

Trello lends itself really nicely to Scrum. To get started with your first Sprint

- Create a new Trello Board for your team or project
- Map out your process (from todo to done) as Lists on your Board. Include a 'Sprint Backlog' List
- Add the cards for the current Sprint to your Sprint Backlog
- [Optional] create Checklists on Cards if you have subtasks
- Invite your team and assign members to Cards
- Add labels (ie Bug, Blocked) to Cards if needed
- Once your Sprint is complete, keep the same board and add the next Sprint into the Sprint Backlog
- [Optional] if you really want to get the most from Scrum it is worth installing a Power-Up like [Corrello Agile Metrics](https://trello.com/power-ups/568c2b6c7d2758a55ac48c98/agile-dashboards-by-corrello) or [Burndowns for Trello](https://trello.com/power-ups/5eda444d3be9d07a01eb82a4/burndowns-by-corrello)


## Our other Power-Ups for Trello

**[Kanban WIP](https://trello.com/power-ups/5e621e477907d7774380f551/kanban-wip-by-corrello)**. Allows you to set up WIP limits which will apply across multiple lists.

**[Agile Tools](https://trello.com/power-ups/59d4ef8cfea15a55b0086614/agile-tools-by-corrello)**. Lets you add story points to cards (integrates with Corrello) and set WIP limits for individual lists.

**[Time in List](https://trello.com/power-ups/5b4765f383dd7c75d8e57be4/time-in-list)**. Does what it says on the tin! Super simple time in list tracking for Trello.

Looking for general purpose **[Trello Reporting](https://trello.com/power-ups/5d9c90aa18965066fcd44730/reports-by-blue-cat)?** Blue Cat Reports is our general purpose Reporting solution for Trello. Build the charts you want, drag and drop to create the dashboard how your team needs it.


[Import to Trello by Blue Cat](https://trello.com/power-ups/61fa6cd2cc14647c2c9ee821/trello-import-by-blue-cat) lets you easily import CSV, Excel and Google Sheets into Trello.

[Forms by Blue Cat](https://trello.com/power-ups/6139de588901011c01baf52f/forms-by-blue-cat) lets you create forms which create cards on your Trello vards, it integrates with all the standard and custom Trello fields as well as attachments. 

### [Exports for Trello](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel)

Export your data from Trello, manually for free or pay to get scheduled exports direct to your inbox. Our [Exports Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/646c9004a20404e02facd050/exports-for-trello-by-blue-cat-csv-excel) does just that.


## Our Trello guides

See our guide to [all the free power-ups for Trello](https://www.bluecatreports.com/free-trello-powerups/)

Check out our reviews of [every reporting power-up available](https://www.bluecatreports.com/trello-reporting/)

One of the great parts of Trello is the Power-Ups! We've added a few to this Board which we think are worth checking out. Take a look at https://trello.com/c/vaGVfrdg/2-meet-the-power-ups to get a quick intro to those.

cards.name: WELCOME - Start here

cards.desc:
Your Sprints are the beating heart of your Scrum Process. They regulate the whole rhythm of your development process.

## Your Current Sprint Backlog
![Sprint Backlog](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/imagesfortemplates/current-sprint.png)

The **Sprint Backlog** holds all the Cards for the current Sprint. Cards should not be added to this List once the Sprint has started, except in extreme circumstances and after discussion with the team. 

At the top we have the **Sprint Goal** which you can fill in during Sprint Planning. Having a Sprint Goal set helps keep everyone focussed on what the team is trying to achieve each Sprint. This way, when new work comes up it is easier to decide if it fits with the Sprint Goal and can be handled now, or should be put off until later.

## The Next Sprint
![Next Sprint](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/imagesfortemplates/next-sprint.png)

The **Next Sprint** List is the place to start logging the Cards you think will be in the next Sprint. When you have your Sprint Planning meeting the team can look at these Cards first when pulling Cards into the Sprint Backlog. Note, the team should take responsibility for deciding which Cards come into each Sprint.

> **Aside: Why does the Team control the contents of the Sprint?** You might wonder why the team controls what is added to the Sprint Backlog each Sprint, and why they can control what is then added during the Sprint. The idea is that by giving the team control over this, they can take ownership of whether the work for each Sprint was completed. As they get used to committing to work, and completing it all they will not want to miss completing future Sprints. When Sprint contents are decided externally it is very easy to explain away missing the Sprint Goal as the result of those external changes.

## Future Sprints
![Backlog](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/imagesfortemplates/backlog.png)

All work not in the Current Sprint or planned for the Next Sprint is in the **Backlog** List. This should be in priority order, so the next Card to be worked on is ideally the first in the List.

## How long should a Sprint be?

Recommendations for Sprint lengths have changed over time and in truth you need to find what works for your team. There are just 3 rules I would ask you to follow

### 1. All Sprints should be the same length 

Every Sprint should be the same length. This gives the team a chance to get a feeling for how much work they can get done in a Sprint. It also lets them get into a consistent rhythm of starting and completing Sprints. 

If you find you think you need a longer Sprint to complete some piece of work you will need to find a way to divide that work into smaller chunks. By doing so you also make it easier to spot issues with the work earlier. Rather than waiting for one single large piece of work to be completed you will know if some smaller individual step has been missed ahead of the whole piece of work being missed.

### 2. Start/end on the same day every time

Much like the above, there should be no need to end a sprint, wait some unknown number of days then start the next one. As one Sprint ends another can start (either that day or the next). Again, this lets people get into a consistent rhythm with their work. Ie Mondays are always Sprint start day, Fridays Sprint end day. Maybe the team has a celebration on Fridays to mark the end of each Sprint. 

### 3. Stick between 1-4 weeks for your Sprints

Typically teams will run Sprints of between 1 and 4 weeks, with most teams tending towards 1-2 weeks. As a general rule I would say to push yourself towards the 1-2 week end of the spectrum. You can always modify the sprints in future if you need to change from a 2 to a 3 week Sprint.

With a 1-2 week Sprint your team can probably remember quite well what they did during the Sprint. It is also a lot easier to predict how much work might get done in a Sprint when it is a shorter length. And, as mentioned above, shorter Sprints give you more chances to monitor progress and change direction.
cards.name: Managing your Sprints

cards.desc:
We will look below at the **Lists**, **Labels** and the **Template Card** on this Board. If you aren't sure what is best for your team, stick with something close to what we have initially then change it as you learn what works best for you 😊

# Lists

See https://trello.com/c/w15oRdgG/14-managing-your-sprints for details on the Backlog Lists.

## 'Doing' Lists

![Scrum: Dev, Code Review, Test Lists](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/imagesfortemplates/scrum_doing_lists.png)

The process this Board assumes you will follow once a Card is started is this 

- Dev
- Code Review
- Test

We would encourage you to remove/add/change Lists to better match your process. For example, you may not have a strict 'Code Review' step as part of your team's process so could remove or rename that List. 

You could just have a single 'Doing' List which covers everything between Sprint Backlog and Done. However, breaking out your process into the individual steps makes it easier for people to see where each Card is. With a single List it may not be obvious a Card is ready for Code Review or Test, but with individual Lists for each step the team can more easily self organise to tackle the work.

## Completed Lists

![Done this Sprint](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/imagesfortemplates/done_this_sprint.png)

This Board starts with just one Done list, for Cards completed in the current sprint. When you start your first sprint change the List name to include the dates of the sprint. 

Although there are various ways you could manage your completed Cards we suggest you **create a new Done List for each sprint** to the left of the previous Done list. This is a nice simple way to keep track of what was done when. As Lists become less relevant you can archive them to keep the Board clear.

# Labels

![Labels](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/imagesfortemplates/scrum_doing_lists.png)

We have added just 3 Labels, if you need to add a lot of additional Labels to your Cards we would recommend using the [Custom Fields Power-Up](https://trello.com/power-ups/56d5e249a98895a9797bebb9/custom-fields) to set up Drop Down fields.

## Blocked

Used for Cards which are blocked. Press `3` when hovering over a Card to add/remove this Label

Using a Label for blocked Cards rather than a List allows you to see where in the process your Cards are getting blocked.

## Expedite

This may or may not be useful for your team. If you have the notion of tasks which need more rapid progress through the Board then use this Label. This makes it clear on the front of every Card that it needs to be the next thing worked on at every step.  Press `1` when hovering over a Card to add/remove this Label

## Bug

Used for Bugs. Press `4` when hovering over a Card to add/remove this Label

# Template Card

We have also added a **Template Card** to this Board. Template Cards let you define some elements of your Cards you want to reuse often. In this case we have added checklists for the Definition of Done and the Definition of Ready. If you want more details on either of those check out the **About this Board** section on the right hand Board menu.

We have started with nothing in your Definition of Done and Ready, these should be created in collaboration with the team.

To create new Cards from your template Card you can use the **create from template** button on the bottom of your Lists

![Create from Template](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/imagesfortemplates/create_from_template.png)
cards.name: Customise your Board

cards.desc:
We've added a few different Power-Ups you might want to consider using on this Board. 

Below we introduce each Power-Up and show you how to **get started** with each one.

# Corrello - For Burndowns, Velocity and other Charts/Metrics

**Price:** $5/member monthly (2 week Free Trial)

[Corrello](https://getcorrello.com/?utm_source=trello&utm_medium=template&utm_campaign=scrum_board) adds Charts and Metrics for Scrum Teams using Trello. The key chart this wil add for your team is the Burndown Chart, but it is worth investigating some of the others as well.

[![Corrello Burndown for Trello](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/explainers/burndown-what-is.png)](https://getcorrello.com/?utm_source=trello&utm_medium=template&utm_campaign=scrum_board)


## Getting started

Simply Click on the **Corrello** button on the top right of this Board and set up your free trial. Create a new dashboard for this Board and you will start seeing all the charts and metrics a Scrum team could want as well as daily email (and Slack) updates.

# Agile Tools - For Story Points

**Price:** FREE

If your team are using Story Points then the Free [Agile Tools](https://trello.com/power-ups/59d4ef8cfea15a55b0086614/agile-tools-by-corrello) Power-Up is the simplest way to add them. Story Points from Agile Tools are fully integrated with Corrello Dashbaords.

## Getting started

Click on the 'Get started with Agile Tools' button on top of this Board to get started

[![Agile Story Points](https://app.getcorrello.com/public/images/imagesfortemplates/list_points.png)](https://getcorrello.com/AgileTools/?utm_source=trello&utm_medium=template&utm_campaign=scrum_board)


# Github - For... Github!

**Price:** FREE

The [Github](https://github.com/) Power-Up lets you attach pull requests, issues, branches, and more directly to their respective Cards.

![Github Pup](https://github.trello.services/images/screenshots/GitHub_2.jpg)

## Getting started

Click on the Github button on the Back of any Card to attach PRs and etc to it.
